elements.content: Crystals of [Li(inox)(H2O)] (where inox– = the isonicotinate-N-oxide ion) are obtained from aqueous solution. The Li+ cations and the carboxylate anions form a two-dimensional (2D) sheet containing four-membered (−Li–O–Li–O−) rings and 16-membered (−Li–O–C–O−)4 rings; the sheets are linked to adjacent parallel sheets through hydrogen bonds. Crystals of solvent-free [Li(inox)], obtained from t-butanol, consist of a three-dimensional network which can also be prepared in microcrystalline form by dehydration of [Li(inox)(H2O)] at 200 °C. Crystals of [Ca(inox)2(H2O)2] contain 2D sheets with 4,4 topology in which Ca2+ ions, bound by trans water molecules, provide the 4-connecting nodes. The Ca(H2O)2 2+ units are linked by carboxylate groups to generate 16-membered (−Ca–O–C–O−)4 rings. Sheets are bound together by hydrogen bonds between the pyridine-N-oxide units and coordinated water molecules. [Ca(inox)2(H2O)2] can be dehydrated at 190 °C in a single crystal-to-single crystal transformation to give [Ca(inox)2] whose structure is related to that of the hydrated precursor. A proposed solid-state mechanism for this single crystal-to-single crystal transformation, in which the N-oxide takes up the site on calcium vacated by water is proposed.

Crystals of solvent-free [Li(inox)], obtained from t-butanol, consist of a three-dimensional network which can also be prepared in microcrystalline form by dehydration of [Li(inox)(H2O)] at 200 °C. Crystals of [Ca(inox)2(H2O)2] contain 2D sheets with 4,4 topology in which Ca2+ ions, bound by trans water molecules, provide the 4-connecting nodes. The Ca(H2O)2 2+ units are linked by carboxylate groups to generate 16-membered (-Ca-O-C-O-)4 rings. A proposed solid-state mechanism for this single crystal-to-single crystal transformation, in which the N-oxide takes up the site on calcium vacated by water is proposed.

elements.content: Two-dimensional structures formed by linking hydrated Li+ or Ca2+ ions with carboxylate units, belonging to isonicotinate-N-oxide ions, are transformed into three-dimensional networks upon dehydration. In the case of the Ca-based compound, the transformation occurs with retention of single crystal character.
elements.clean_text: Two-dimensional structures formed by linking hydrated Li+ or Ca2+ ions with carboxylate units, belonging to isonicotinate-N-oxide ions, are transformed into three-dimensional networks upon dehydration. In the case of the Ca-based compound, the transformation occurs with retention of single crystal character.

elements.content: As part of our investigations of lightweight porous networks, we have recently reported a series of framework materials composed of Li+ and inic– (where inic– is the isonicotinate ion, I) that are bound together by essentially ionic interactions. Single crystal structure determinations indicated that connectivity changes within the host network accompany the loss of solvent to produce a material that is able to sorb significant quantities of gases such as hydrogen, nitrogen, methane, and carbon dioxide. Some of the structural rearrangements that occurred upon solvent loss were found to be reversible. The ability of the network to undergo significant reorganization of network components with retention of crystallinity was attributed to the “plasticity” of the ionic interactions between the anion and the lithium cation.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

As part of our investigations of lightweight porous networks, we have recently reported a series of framework materials composed of Li+ and inic- (where inic- is the isonicotinate ion, I) that are bound together by essentially ionic interactions. Single crystal structure determinations indicated that connectivity changes within the host network accompany the loss of solvent to produce a material that is able to sorb significant quantities of gases such as hydrogen, nitrogen, methane, and carbon dioxide. Some of the structural rearrangements that occurred upon solvent loss were found to be reversible. The ability of the network to undergo significant reorganization of network components with retention of crystallinity was attributed to the "plasticity" of the ionic interactions between the anion and the lithium cation.

elements.content: In an effort to further explore the nature and properties of networks in which the components are held together by what are essentially ionic interactions, we have undertaken investigations of the materials formed when the N-oxide derivative of the isonicotinate ion, II (hereafter inox–), is combined with metal ions such as Li+ and Ca2+. A wide range of network solids in which the inox– ligand bridges metal cations of the f-block, the d-block, and the main groups have been reported. The structural diversity seen in these inox– derivatives reveals many different combinations of roles that the two ends of II can play. Its carboxylate end is observed to act sometimes as a monodentate ligand but more often as a μ2 bridge. The N-oxide end may act as a monodentate ligand or as a μ2 bridge, and in other cases it may fail to interact directly with the metal ion.

Microanalyses were performed by either the Microanalytical Unit in the Research School of Chemistry at the Australian National University or the Campbell Microanalytical Laboratory at the University of Otago, NZ.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Procedures

Commercially available reagents employed in the synthesis of the compounds reported were used without further purification. Microanalyses were performed by either the Microanalytical Unit in the Research School of Chemistry at the Australian National University or the Campbell Microanalytical Laboratory at the University of Otago, NZ.

elements.content: Hinox (100 mg, 0.72 mmol) and an equivalent amount of LiOH·H2O (30 mg, 0.72 mmol) were dissolved in boiling H2O (10 mL). Evaporation almost to dryness by exposure to the atmosphere gave colorless plate crystals. Yield: 79 mg. Elemental analysis: Found: C 44.3, N 8.5, H 3.6%. Calcd: C 44.2, N 8.6, H 3.7%.
elements.clean_text:
Syntheses

[Li(inox)(H2O)]

Hinox (100 mg, 0.72 mmol) and an equivalent amount of LiOH⋅H2O (30 mg, 0.72 mmol) were dissolved in boiling H2O (10 mL). Evaporation almost to dryness by exposure to the atmosphere gave colorless plate crystals. Yield: 79 mg. Elemental analysis: Found: C 44.3, N 8.5, H 3.6%. Calcd: C 44.2, N 8.6, H 3.7%.

elements.content: Hinox (50 mg, 0.36 mmol) and an equivalent amount of LiOH·H2O (15 mg, 0.36 mmol) were dissolved in boiling MeOH (5 mL). t-Butanol (5 mL) was added to the boiling solution. The reaction mixture was kept at a constant temperature of 50 °C in an open vessel. The gradual selective evaporation of MeOH led to the separation of rodlike crystals within 24 h. Yield: 33 mg. Elemental analysis: Found: C 44.4, N 8.6, H 3.9%. Calcd for [Li(inox)]·H2O: C 44.2, N 8.6, H 3.7%.
elements.clean_text:
[Li(inox)]

Hinox (50 mg, 0.36 mmol) and an equivalent amount of LiOH⋅H2O (15 mg, 0.36 mmol) were dissolved in boiling MeOH (5 mL). t-Butanol (5 mL) was added to the boiling solution. The reaction mixture was kept at a constant temperature of 50 °C in an open vessel. The gradual selective evaporation of MeOH led to the separation of rodlike crystals within 24 h. Yield: 33 mg. Elemental analysis: Found: C 44.4, N 8.6, H 3.9%. Calcd for [Li(inox)]⋅H2O: C 44.2, N 8.6, H 3.7%.

elements.content: A crystalline sample of [Li(inox)(H2O)] was placed under a flow of N2 gas in a tube furnace which was gradually heated to 200 °C and held there for several hours to yield microcrystalline [Li(inox)] whose powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) was essentially identical to that calculated from the single crystal data for authentic [Li(inox)] obtained from t-butanol as indicated above. Exposure of [Li(inox)] to the atmosphere over a period of 3 weeks led to conversion of the dehydrated form to the hydrated form as indicated by powder XRD.
elements.clean_text:
Reversible Conversion of [Li(inox)(H2O)] to [Li(inox)]

A crystalline sample of [Li(inox)(H2O)] was placed under a flow of N2 gas in a tube furnace which was gradually heated to 200 °C and held there for several hours to yield microcrystalline [Li(inox)] whose powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) was essentially identical to that calculated from the single crystal data for authentic [Li(inox)] obtained from t-butanol as indicated above. Exposure of [Li(inox)] to the atmosphere over a period of 3 weeks led to conversion of the dehydrated form to the hydrated form as indicated by powder XRD.

elements.content: A solution containing 2:1 proportions of Hinox (50 mg, 0.36 mmol) and Ca(OAc)2 (28 mg, 0.18 mmol) in boiling H2O (10 mL) was gradually evaporated down to a small volume yielding thin colorless plates. Yield: 72 mg. Elemental analysis: Found: C 41.0, N 8.0, H 3.4%. Calcd for [Ca(inox)2(H2O)2]: C 40.9, N 8.0, H 3.4%.
elements.clean_text:
[Ca(inox)2(H2O)2]

A solution containing 2:1 proportions of Hinox (50 mg, 0.36 mmol) and Ca(OAc)2 (28 mg, 0.18 mmol) in boiling H2O (10 mL) was gradually evaporated down to a small volume yielding thin colorless plates. Yield: 72 mg. Elemental analysis: Found: C 41.0, N 8.0, H 3.4%. Calcd for [Ca(inox)2(H2O)2]: C 40.9, N 8.0, H 3.4%.

elements.content: Crystals of [Ca(inox)2(H2O)2] under a flow of N2 gas were gradually heated to 190 °C and held at that temperature for 6 h. No obvious change in external appearance and morphology was observed after the dehydration, and the anhydrous crystals were suitable for single crystal X-ray structural analysis. Elemental analysis: Found: C 41.0, N 8.1, H 3.5%. Calcd for [Ca(inox)2]·2H2O (water being reabsorbed from the atmosphere) C 40.9, N 8.0, H 3.4%.
elements.clean_text:
[Ca(inox)2]

Crystals of [Ca(inox)2(H2O)2] under a flow of N2 gas were gradually heated to 190 °C and held at that temperature for 6 h. No obvious change in external appearance and morphology was observed after the dehydration, and the anhydrous crystals were suitable for single crystal X-ray structural analysis. Elemental analysis: Found: C 41.0, N 8.1, H 3.5%. Calcd for [Ca(inox)2]⋅2H2O (water being reabsorbed from the atmosphere) C 40.9, N 8.0, H 3.4%.

elements.content: Crystals of [Ca(inox)2] were exposed to the atmosphere over a period of 24 h. Some cracking of the crystals was apparent. A crystalline fragment with good internal clarity was selected from this sample and investigated using single crystal X-ray diffraction, which unambiguously indicated that the [Ca(inox)2] had reconverted to its hydrated form [Ca(inox)2(H2O)2].
elements.clean_text:
Conversion of [Ca(inox)2] to [Ca(inox)2(H2O)2]

Crystals of [Ca(inox)2] were exposed to the atmosphere over a period of 24 h. Some cracking of the crystals was apparent. A crystalline fragment with good internal clarity was selected from this sample and investigated using single crystal X-ray diffraction, which unambiguously indicated that the [Ca(inox)2] had reconverted to its hydrated form [Ca(inox)2(H2O)2].

elements.content: The crystallographic data for [Li(inox)(H2O)], [Li(inox)], and [Ca(inox)2(H2O)2] were collected at 130 K on an Excalibur, Sapphire 3 Oxford Diffractometer fitted with a CuKα radiation (1.54184 Å) source. and those for [Ca(inox)2] and its rehydrated form were collected at 130 K on a SuperNova Oxford Diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation. Numerical absorption corrections were carried out using a multifaceted crystal model, and the ABSPACK routine within the CrysAlis software package. All five structures were solved by direct methods (SHELXS-97) and refined using a full-matrix least-squares procedure based on F 2 (SHELXL-97). Crystallographic analysis was performed using the WinGX system of programs. Crystallographic data and structural refinement parameters are presented in Table except for the rehydrated form of [Ca(inox)2], which is included in the . Full details of crystal structure refinements in CIF format are available as .

Numerical absorption corrections were carried out using a multifaceted crystal model, and the ABSPACK routine within the CrysAlis software package. All five structures were solved by direct methods (SHELXS-97) and refined using a full-matrix least-squares procedure based on F 2 (SHELXL-97). Crystallographic analysis was performed using the WinGX system of programs. Crystallographic data and structural refinement parameters are presented in Table  except for the rehydrated form of [Ca(inox)2], which is included in the . elements.content:
Thermogravimetric analyses were performed on an SDDTA851 Mettler-Toledo analyzer. Analyses were performed on freshly prepared samples under a nitrogen atmosphere.

Results and Discussion

Colorless crystals of composition [Li(inox)(H2O)] can be obtained from aqueous solutions containing equivalent amounts of Hinox and LiOH·H2O. The crystals are monoclinic, space group P21/a, with cell dimensions: a = 7.9669(5) Å, b = 9.9375(7) Å, c = 8.7046(5) Å, β = 90.186(5)°. Sheets of composition [Li(inox)(H2O)] shown in Figure a,b are present. All inox– units are equivalent, one carboxylate oxygen center being attached to a single Li+ center and the other oxygen bridging between two Li+ centers. All Li+ centers are equivalent and participate in four-membered Li–O–Li–O rings (Figure a). Each Li+ cation is surrounded by a roughly tetrahedrally arranged group of oxygen centers, comprised of two bridging carboxylate oxygen atoms that form part of the aforementioned four-membered rings, together with a monodentate carboxylate oxygen atom and a water molecule. The sheet has a 4-connected topology the nodes of which are provided by Li2O2 aggregates. The pyridine N-oxide units do not interact directly with the metal cations; as can be seen in Figure b some are inclined above and some below the average plane of the sheet. The N-oxide center is hydrogen bonded (O···O, 2.754 Å) to a water molecule attached to Li+ on the opposite side of the 16-membered (−Li–O–C-O−)4 rings that can be seen in Figure b. The two pyridine-N-oxide units inclined above and below the center of each 16-membered ring are related by a center of symmetry and make relatively close contact with each other (closest C···C separation, 3.45 Å).
elements.clean_text:
Thermogravimetric Measurements

Thermogravimetric analyses were performed on an SDDTA851 Mettler-Toledo analyzer. Analyses were performed on freshly prepared samples under a nitrogen atmosphere.

Results and Discussion

Colorless crystals of composition [Li(inox)(H2O)] can be obtained from aqueous solutions containing equivalent amounts of Hinox and LiOH⋅H2O. The crystals are monoclinic, space group P21/a, with cell dimensions: a = 7.9669(5) Å, b = 9.9375(7) Å, c = 8.7046(5) Å, β = 90.186(5)°. Sheets of composition [Li(inox)(H2O)] shown in Figure a,b are present. All inox- units are equivalent, one carboxylate oxygen center being attached to a single Li+ center and the other oxygen bridging between two Li+ centers. All Li+ centers are equivalent and participate in four-membered Li-O-Li-O rings (Figure a). Each Li+ cation is surrounded by a roughly tetrahedrally arranged group of oxygen centers, comprised of two bridging carboxylate oxygen atoms that form part of the aforementioned four-membered rings, together with a monodentate carboxylate oxygen atom and a water molecule. The sheet has a 4-connected topology the nodes of which are provided by Li2O2 aggregates. The pyridine N-oxide units do not interact directly with the metal cations; as can be seen in Figure b some are inclined above and some below the average plane of the sheet. The N-oxide center is hydrogen bonded (O⋅⋅⋅O, 2.754 Å) to a water molecule attached to Li+ on the opposite side of the 16-membered (-Li-O-C-O-)4 rings that can be seen in Figure b. The two pyridine-N-oxide units inclined above and below the center of each 16-membered ring are related by a center of symmetry and make relatively close contact with each other (closest C⋅⋅⋅C separation, 3.45 Å).

elements.content: Structure of [Li(inox)(H2O)] showing: (a) A representation of part of the [Li(inox)(H2O)] sheet in which, for clarity, only the −Li–O–C–O– interactions are shown. (b) A view of the same section of the [Li(inox)(H2O)] sheet including all interactions. The black and white banded connections represent N-oxide-to-water hydrogen bonds (O···O, 2.754 Å). (c) A representation of the region between sheets, showing the hydrogen bonding (represented by black and white banded connections) between an N-oxide in one and a water molecule in the neighbor (O···O, 2.733 Å). Thin black lines indicate close N···N contacts of 3.206 Å; intrasheet hydrogen bond interactions are not indicated. Hydrogen atoms have been omitted for clarity. Color code: O red; N blue; C black, Li green.

elements.content: The [Li(inox)(H2O)] sheets, interrelated by translations along the a axis, are bound to neighbors by hydrogen bonds between N-oxide centers in one sheet and water molecules in the neighboring sheet (O···O, 2.733 Å) in the manner shown in Figure c. Every N-oxide center is thus involved in hydrogen bonds to two water moleculesone within its own sheet (as in Figure b) and one in the neighboring sheet (as in Figure c). Likewise, every water molecule is involved in hydrogen bonds to two N-oxide centersone within its own sheet and one in the neighboring sheet. Close N···N contacts of 3.206 Å, between pyridyl nitrogen atoms from separate sheets, represented in Figure c by thin black lines, suggest a face-to-face attraction between inox– anions.

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analysis of [Li(inox)(H2O)] reveals that at atmospheric pressure the water is lost in the temperature range 180–230 °C (calcd 11.0%, found 11.0%). The crystals lose their single crystal character during this dehydration. The anhydrous material does however remain crystalline, giving a well-resolved XRD powder pattern (). This pattern is essentially identical to that calculated on the basis of the single crystal-determined structure of solvent-free Li(inox) which can be obtained from hot t-butanol solutions containing equivalent amounts of Hinox and LiOH·H2O. Anhydrous [Li(inox)] crystallizes from t-butanol in the monoclinic space group, I2/a with cell dimensions: a = 13.5472(6) Å, b = 8.7132(5) Å, c = 10.7662(4) Å, β = 99.987(10)°.

elements.content: In solvent-free [Li(inox)] crystals, the Li+ and inox– ions are arranged into an extended three-dimensional (3D) network which is most simply envisaged in terms of strips of the type shown in Figure a,b, all of which run parallel. Half the pyridine-N-oxide units in a strip are inclined upward relative to the average plane of the Li+ centers in the strip and half are inclined downward, as can be clearly seen in Figure b. The strips are related to each other by a simple translation; i.e., the average planes of the Li+ centers in the strips are all parallel and identically oriented. All Li+ cations in [Li(inox)] are equivalent and are surrounded by oxygen atoms that form an approximately tetrahedral arrangement around the Li+ centers. The oxygen atoms belong to carboxylate groups from three separate inox– anions, all forming part of the same strip (Figure a) and an N-oxide center from a fourth inox– unit, which is part of a neighboring strip. The Li to N-oxide interactions bind each strip to four others as shown in Figure c. A more detailed view of the binding of one strip to a neighbor is shown in Figure d. An N-oxide center of one strip bonds to a Li+ center in a neighboring strip, and, in a complementary fashion, an N-oxide center from the second strip forms a bond to a Li+ center in the first strip. The extended 3D network shown in Figure e is thereby generated. As indicated earlier, this 3D [Li(inox)] structure can be generated by dehydration of [Li(inox)(H2O)], which has the 2D sheet structure described above.

elements.content: The reversibility of the dehydration process was examined by exposing [Li(inox)] to the atmosphere. After 24 h the powder XRD pattern revealed that the [Li(inox)] was still in its dehyrdrated form; however, after a period of 3 weeks, powder XRD clearly indicated the Li(inox) had undergone complete conversion to [Li(inox)(H2O)]. The powder pattern on the rehydrated material is in excellent agreement with the simulated pattern based upon the single crystal structure determination of [Li(inox)(H2O)] (see ).

elements.content: Crystals of composition [Ca(inox)2(H2O)2] separate when aqueous solutions containing Hinox and calcium acetate are allowed partially to evaporate; the compound crystallizes in the monoclinic space group, P21/c, with cell dimensions: a = 7.9541(2) Å, b = 9.8412(3) Å, c = 8.8672(3) Å, β = 95.500(3)°. Sheets of composition [Ca(inox)2(H2O)2] are present, in which all Ca2+ centers are equivalent and all inox– units also are equivalent. Figure a,b shows a view of part of a sheet. The Ca2+ cations are surrounded by six oxygen centers. Four of the oxygen centers belong to four carboxylate groups from separate inox– units; two trans water molecules complete a distorted octahedral environment around each Ca2+ center. As can be seen in Figure a, each Ca2+ ion is connected to four others by inox– bridges to generate a 2D net with 4,4 topology that somewhat resembles the Li(inox) sheets seen in [Li(inox)(H2O)] (see Figure a) but with 4-connecting Ca2+ in place of the 4-connecting Li2O2 assemblies. The water molecules and the pyridyl N-oxide components of the inox– units constitute appendages to the 2D Ca/carboxylate network, projecting above and below the average plane occupied by the Ca2+ centers (Figure b). Sixteen-membered (−Ca–O–C–O−)4 rings are present, each of which is associated with two pyridyl units, as can be seen in Figure b, one inclined above and one below the central region of the 16-membered ring. As in the case of [Li(inox)(H2O)], the [Ca(inox)2(H2O)2] sheets are stacked directly one on top of another, related by translations along the a axis. The sheets are bound together in the manner shown in Figure c by hydrogen bonds between the coordinated water molecules in one sheet and the pyridyl N-oxide groups in the neighbor (O···O, 2.768 Å). The structural parallels between [Li(inox)(H2O)] and [Ca(inox)2(H2O)2] are reflected in the similarity of the respective cell dimensions (Table ).

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analysis of [Ca(inox)2(H2O)2] indicates that water loss is complete by ∼230 °C. Remarkably, the single crystal character of the hydrated crystals is preserved after dehydration (unlike those of [Li(inox)(H2O)]) allowing a detailed structural analysis of the anhydrous solid. Crystals of anhydrous [Ca(inox)2] retain the same monoclinic space group, P21/c, observed for the hydrated precursor. The new cell dimensions however differ significantly from those of the hydrate: the cell dimensions for anhydrous [Ca(inox)2] are a = 7.0489(6) Å, b = 10.8422(7) Å, c = 8.0341(7) Å, β = 107.826(9)°, whereas those for [Ca(inox)2(H2O)2] are a = 7.9541(2) Å, b = 9.8412(3) Å, c = 8.8672(3) Å, β = 95.500(3)°. The structure of [Ca(inox)2] consists of a 3D network which can be most simply envisaged in terms of the hypothetical solid state mechanism we propose here for its generation from the hydrate. All Ca2+ ions in [Ca(inox)2] are equivalent and, like those in the hydrate, are in an approximately octahedral environment, but now the two trans water molecules have been replaced by two trans N-oxide oxygen centers, as can be seen by comparing Figure a with Figure b. All that is required to generate the Ca(inox)2 structure seen in Figure a from the [Ca(inox)2(H2O)2] structure seen in Figure b is to remove the water molecules and move the sheets relative to each other so that the N-oxide oxygen center takes up the position vacated by the water molecule to which it had been hydrogen bonded. Since the O···O separation in the hydrogen bonds in question is 2.768 Å, this movement is necessarily considerable, consisting of the sliding of one sheet relative to the other, the bringing of the sheets closer together, and the minor deformation of the sheets in the manner described below. The sheet–sheet separation in the hydrate crystal is ∼7.92 Å, which becomes ∼6.71 Å in the anhydrous crystal, a reduction of approximately 15%. Likewise, the cell volume decreases upon dehydration by roughly 15% from 690.9 Å3 to 584.5 Å3. An important feature of this proposed solid state mechanism is that it does not require the disruption of any of the Ca2+-inox– bondsthe connectivity within the sheets remains unchanged. Minor swiveling of the inox– units relative to the associated calcium centers is required to optimize the new N-oxide-Ca2+ bonding, and this is achieved, as described below, by distortion of the 16-membered (−Ca–O–C–O−)4 rings shown in Figure . It can be seen by visual comparison of the Ca4 ring in [Ca(inox)2(H2O)2]. [Figure c(i)] with that in [Ca(inox)2] [Figure c(ii)] that the two “inner” inox– units need to swing around, upon dehydration, so as to adopt a position with their oxygen atoms close to vertically above (or below) the Ca2+ center to which they are to become attached. This is achieved by twisting the two “inner” inox– units as rigid blocks so that their carboxylate O···O vectors become closer to horizontal as seen in Figure . The consequence of this is that the Ca4 rhombus becomes elongated along the horizontal diagonal and, necessarily at the same time, shortened along the vertical diagonal. The Ca···Ca diagonals seen horizontal in Figure c correspond to the b dimension of the unit cell; this Ca···Ca diagonal separation, which is 9.8412(3) Å for [Ca(inox)2(H2O)2] seen in Figure c(i), is expanded to 10.8422(7) Å in [Ca(inox)2] seen in Figure c(ii). The Ca···Ca diagonals seen vertical in Figure c correspond to the c dimension of the unit cell, which is 8.8672(3) Å for [Ca(inox)2(H2O)2] in Figure c(i) and is contracted to 8.0341(7) Å in [Ca(inox)2] seen in Figure c(ii). The contractions accompanying dehydration along a and c and the expansion along b are thus readily understood. In the [Ca(inox)2] structure the inox– and Ca2+ components act as 3-connecting and 6-connecting nodes respectively, and it is interesting to note that the topology of the network generated is that of the archetype rutile.

elements.content: Comparative representations of the Ca(inox)2 network in [Ca(inox)2(H2O)2] and [Ca(inox)2]. (a) A view of fragments, each containing eight Ca2+ centers, from four separate sheets in the [Ca(inox)2] structure. The sheets are presented here in the horizontal plane and are seen almost “edge-on”. The Ca2+ centers are octahedral with two trans N-oxides. For clarity the figure has been curtailed to a “depth” into the page of only one Ca–O–C–O–Ca edge of a (−Ca–O–C–O−)4 16-membered ring and only the two inox– units located within the Ca8 parallelepipeds are shown. (b) An equivalent view of the same four sheets in [Ca(inox)2(H2O)2]. Each Ca2+ carries two trans water molecules, but, for clarity, only water molecules that are hydrogen bonded to those inox– units that are included in the figure are shown. (c) Views of the (−Ca–O–C–O−)4 16-membered rings in (i) [Ca(inox)2(H2O)2] and (ii) [Ca(inox)2]. The Ca···Ca diagonals seen horizontal here correspond to the b dimension of the unit cell viz., 9.8412(3) Å for [Ca(inox)2(H2O)2] in (i) which is stretched to 10.8422(7) Å in [Ca(inox)] seen in (ii). The Ca···Ca diagonals seen vertical here correspond to the c dimension of the unit cell which is 8.8672(3) Å for [Ca(inox)2(H2O)2] in (i) contracted to 8.0341(7) Å in [Ca(inox)] seen in (ii). Note that upon dehydration the inox– units swing around so that their oxygen centers become located close to the perpendicular passing through the appropriate Ca2+ center. Hydrogen atoms have been omitted for clarity. Color code: Ca green, O red; N blue; C black.

elements.content: When the dehydrated crystals are exposed to air, they are found to undergo visible cracking, but the individual components have improved clarity in comparison to the [Ca(inox)2] crystals (obtained by heating [Ca(inox)2(H2O)2]). Remarkably, single crystal X-ray diffraction studies of a crystalline fragment of the original crystal indicate that [Ca(inox)2] has absorbed water from the atmosphere after a period of 24 h and has converted back to [Ca(inox)2(H2O)2]. Interestingly, the quality of the single crystal data as well as the refinement of the structure is superior to that of the dehydrated form for which the reflections were relatively broad. Details of the structure refinement of the rehydrated crystal are presented in the .

elements.content: Although [Li(inox)] and [Ca(inox)2] can sorb water from the atmosphere, gas sorption studies involving nitrogen at 77 K and carbon dioxide at 273 K indicated no significant sorption (see for details).
elements.clean_text: Although [Li(inox)] and [Ca(inox)2] can sorb water from the atmosphere, gas sorption studies involving nitrogen at 77 K and carbon dioxide at 273 K indicated no significant sorption (see  for details).

elements.content: It was hoped that the isonicotinate-N-oxide ion with Li+ and Ca2+ might generate essentially ionic and microporous solids similar to those obtained with the isonicotinate ion itself, but the exploratory work described here failed to reveal such structures. [Ca(inox)2], obtained by dehydration of [Ca(inox)2(H2O)2] in a single crystal-to-single crystal process, contains sheets with the same Ca–O–C–O–Ca connectivity as those present in the hydrated precursor, but the geometry is significantly different. In this dehydration process, the volume per formula unit decreases by ∼15%, and the sheet-to-sheet separation also decreases by ∼15%, although one of the cell dimensions increases. All the observed structural changes accompanying this dehydration are very satisfactorily accounted for by the solid state mechanism proposed above in which the N-oxide takes up the site on calcium vacated by water, as the sheets become significantly deformed, move closer together, and slide relative to one another.
elements.clean_text:
Concluding Remarks

It was hoped that the isonicotinate-N-oxide ion with Li+ and Ca2+ might generate essentially ionic and microporous solids similar to those obtained with the isonicotinate ion itself, but the exploratory work described here failed to reveal such structures. [Ca(inox)2], obtained by dehydration of [Ca(inox)2(H2O)2] in a single crystal-to-single crystal process, contains sheets with the same Ca-O-C-O-Ca connectivity as those present in the hydrated precursor, but the geometry is significantly different. In this dehydration process, the volume per formula unit decreases by ~15%, and the sheet-to-sheet separation also decreases by ~15%, although one of the cell dimensions increases. All the observed structural changes accompanying this dehydration are very satisfactorily accounted for by the solid state mechanism proposed above in which the N-oxide takes up the site on calcium vacated by water, as the sheets become significantly deformed, move closer together, and slide relative to one another.

elements.content: It is interesting to note that the reversible structural rearrangements that occur upon solvent loss (in the case of Ca2+ with retention of single crystal character) parallels the behavior that was found in our exploration of Li(inic) networks. As indicated in the , the retention of crystallinity in the solid state transformations of the various Li(inic) networks was attributed to the “plasticity” of the ionic interactions between the network components. The results reported here provide further support for the suggestion that the nondirectional nature of ionic interactions facilitates significant structural rearrangements of ionic networks with retention of crystallinity.

As indicated in the , the retention of crystallinity in the solid state transformations of the various Li(inic) networks was attributed to the "plasticity" of the ionic interactions between the network components. The results reported here provide further support for the suggestion that the nondirectional nature of ionic interactions facilitates significant structural rearrangements of ionic networks with retention of crystallinity.

Hinox (100 mg, 0.72 mmol) and an equivalent amount of LiOH·H2O (30 mg, 0.72 mmol) were dissolved in boiling H2O (10 mL). Evaporation almost to dryness by exposure to the atmosphere gave colorless plate crystals. Yield: 79 mg. Elemental analysis: Found: C 44.3, N 8.5, H 3.6%. Calcd: C 44.2, N 8.6, H 3.7%.

[Li(inox)]

Hinox (50 mg, 0.36 mmol) and an equivalent amount of LiOH·H2O (15 mg, 0.36 mmol) were dissolved in boiling MeOH (5 mL). t-Butanol (5 mL) was added to the boiling solution. The reaction mixture was kept at a constant temperature of 50 °C in an open vessel. The gradual selective evaporation of MeOH led to the separation of rodlike crystals within 24 h. Yield: 33 mg. Elemental analysis: Found: C 44.4, N 8.6, H 3.9%. Calcd for [Li(inox)]·H2O: C 44.2, N 8.6, H 3.7%.

[Ca(inox)<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>]

A solution containing 2:1 proportions of Hinox (50 mg, 0.36 mmol) and Ca(OAc)2 (28 mg, 0.18 mmol) in boiling H2O (10 mL) was gradually evaporated down to a small volume yielding thin colorless plates. Yield: 72 mg. Elemental analysis: Found: C 41.0, N 8.0, H 3.4%. Calcd for [Ca(inox)2(H2O)2]: C 40.9, N 8.0, H 3.4%.

cln_elements.content:
Crystals of [Ca(inox)2(H2O)2] under a flow of N2 gas were gradually heated to 190 °C and held at that temperature for 6 h. No obvious change in external appearance and morphology was observed after the dehydration, and the anhydrous crystals were suitable for single crystal X-ray structural analysis. Elemental analysis: Found: C 41.0, N 8.1, H 3.5%. Calcd for [Ca(inox)2]·2H2O (water being reabsorbed from the atmosphere) C 40.9, N 8.0, H 3.4%.

Thermogravimetric analysis of [Li(inox)(H2O)] reveals that at atmospheric pressure the water is lost in the temperature range 180–230 °C (calcd 11.0%, found 11.0%). The crystals lose their single crystal character during this dehydration. The anhydrous material does however remain crystalline, giving a well-resolved XRD powder pattern (). This pattern is essentially identical to that calculated on the basis of the single crystal-determined structure of solvent-free Li(inox) which can be obtained from hot t-butanol solutions containing equivalent amounts of Hinox and LiOH·H2O. Anhydrous [Li(inox)] crystallizes from t-butanol in the monoclinic space group, I2/a with cell dimensions: a = 13.5472(6) Å, b = 8.7132(5) Å, c = 10.7662(4) Å, β = 99.987(10)°.

(c) A representation of the region between sheets, showing the hydrogen bonding (represented by black and white banded connections) between an N-oxide in one and a water molecule in the neighbor (O···O, 2.733 Å). cln_elements.content: Structure of [Ca(inox)2(H2O)2] showing: (a) A representation of part of the [Ca(inox)2(H2O)2] sheet in which, for clarity, only the −Ca–O–C–O– interactions are shown. (b) Part of a sheet in [Ca(inox)2(H2O)2] in which all of the interactions are shown. Water molecules are attached to each Ca2+ ion in a trans fashion. Depth fading here reveals how the inox– units are inclined above and below the average Ca/carboxylate plane. (c) A view showing nine Ca2+ members of an upper sheet (closer to the viewer) and nine Ca2+ members of a lower neighbor (depth faded) and the way in which a sheet is bound to sheet by N-oxide-to-water hydrogen bonds, represented by black and white banded connections (O···O, 2.768 Å). Only the water molecules involved in hydrogen bonding to the intersheet inox– units in this part of the structure are shown. Hydrogen atoms have been omitted for clarity. Color code: Ca green, O red; N blue; C black.

cln_elements.content: Comparative representations of the Ca(inox)2 network in [Ca(inox)2(H2O)2] and [Ca(inox)2]. (a) A view of fragments, each containing eight Ca2+ centers, from four separate sheets in the [Ca(inox)2] structure. The sheets are presented here in the horizontal plane and are seen almost “edge-on”. The Ca2+ centers are octahedral with two trans N-oxides. For clarity the figure has been curtailed to a “depth” into the page of only one Ca–O–C–O–Ca edge of a (−Ca–O–C–O−)4 16-membered ring and only the two inox– units located within the Ca8 parallelepipeds are shown. (b) An equivalent view of the same four sheets in [Ca(inox)2(H2O)2]. Each Ca2+ carries two trans water molecules, but, for clarity, only water molecules that are hydrogen bonded to those inox– units that are included in the figure are shown. (c) Views of the (−Ca–O–C–O−)4 16-membered rings in (i) [Ca(inox)2(H2O)2] and (ii) [Ca(inox)2]. The Ca···Ca diagonals seen horizontal here correspond to the b dimension of the unit cell viz., 9.8412(3) Å for [Ca(inox)2(H2O)2] in (i) which is stretched to 10.8422(7) Å in [Ca(inox)] seen in (ii). The Ca···Ca diagonals seen vertical here correspond to the c dimension of the unit cell which is 8.8672(3) Å for [Ca(inox)2(H2O)2] in (i) contracted to 8.0341(7) Å in [Ca(inox)] seen in (ii). Note that upon dehydration the inox– units swing around so that their oxygen centers become located close to the perpendicular passing through the appropriate Ca2+ center. Hydrogen atoms have been omitted for clarity. Color code: Ca green, O red; N blue; C black.

metadata.title:
Li+ and Ca2+ Derivatives of
the Isonicotinate‑N‑oxide Ion Including
Single Crystal-to-Single Crystal Transformations
